metadata.background_text:
The Flytrap Blame Game 

         One of the few truths universally acknowledged about Flytrap is that presidential secretary Betty Currie deserves our sympathy: an honest, loyal civil servant dragooned into a scandal she had nothing to do with. 

         But does Currie deserve such sanctification? After all, she knew Clinton's history when she took her job then enabled Clinton's sleaziness anyway. She stood by while Clinton cuckolded his wife and perhaps even helped him commit obstruction of justice. And did she protest? Not as far as we have heard. Did she quit on principle? No. Currie may not be Flytrap's chief malefactor, but nor is she the saintly innocent that the American public believes her to be. 

         The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration. 

         Monica Lewinsky, for example, has fantastically low approval ratings, much lower than Clinton's. One poll I saw pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent (even Newt Gingrich manages at least 25 percent). Now, Monica certainly isn't the heroine of Flytrap. She did seduce a married man, damage the presidency for the sake of casual sex, lie frequently and insouciantly, and blab her "secret" affair to anyone who'd listen. But she was also sexually exploited by her older, sleazy boss; had her reputation smeared by Clinton's lackeys; and was betrayed by her "friend" Linda Tripp. She hardly deserves such universal contempt. 

         Others besides Currie have benefited from the public's excessive generosity. George Stephanopoulos has become a white knight of Flytrap, the former Clinton aide who had the courage to turn on his boss. And bravo to George for chastising Clinton! But it smacks of hypocrisy for Stephanopoulos to "discover" in 1998 that Clinton is a lying, womanizing dog. He has, after all known this since 1992. Back then Stephanopoulos himself helped quell bimbo eruptions and parroted Clinton's lying denials. He has never shouldered blame for those deceptions. (Mickey Kaus first noted Stephanopoulos' unbearable sanctimony in this "Chatterbox" item in January.) And while loyalty isn't a universal good, it was opportunistic for Stephanopoulos to betray Clinton just at the moment Clinton's stock was about to plunge. 

          (Sometimes, of course, the public's rating is dead on target. Linda Tripp's allies--a group that includes her lawyers, Kenneth Starr, the Goldberg family, and absolutely no one else as far as I can tell--have tried repeatedly to improve her sorry public image. Jonah Goldberg tried right here in Slate. No sale.) 

          Below is                    Slate                's entire scorecard, which ranks 31 of Flytrap's key players: The scale runs from -10 to +10. Anything less than zero means the player is a net miscreant. Anything above zero rates a sympathy card. (This is not, of course, an exact science. How, for example, do we judge Ann Lewis compared to other last ditch Clinton defenders? Lewis is said to be more outraged by Clinton's misbehavior than The Guys in the White House. Yet Lewis didn't quit in disgust. Is her outrage a plus or a minus if she doesn't act on it? You decide.) 

         The Scorecard 

                         Bill Clinton (The public's rating: -6 ) 

         Minuses: 

         To recapitulate 

         a) Had an adulterous affair with a young intern. 

         b) Lied about it to everyone . 

         c) Probably perjured himself. 

         d) Perhaps obstructed justice. 

         e) Entangled allies and aides in his web of deceit. 

         f) Humiliated his wife and daughter. 

         g) Did not have the grace to apologize to Lewinsky. 

         h)Tried to shift the blame for his failures onto his accusers. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Had his private life exposed to the world in a way no one's should be. 

         b) Has been persecuted by enemies who won't be satisfied until he is destroyed. 

                                            Slate                 rating-- He never asked for our sympathy, and he doesn't deserve it: -9              

                         Dick Morris (The public's rating: -6 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Encouraged Clinton's most deplorable habits: lying and polling. (When Clinton revealed his adultery to Morris, the political consultant immediately took a poll to see how America would respond to a Clinton admission. When the results suggested Americans would be angry if Clinton had perjured himself, Morris encouraged Clinton to deny the affair.) 

         b) Further sullied the Clintons with a revolting comment suggesting that Clinton cheats because Hillary is a lesbian. 

         c) Not even loyal enough to keep his mouth shut. 

         Pluses: I cannot think of any. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: -7              

                         Linda Tripp (The public's rating: -7 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Betrayed her "friend." 

         b) Obsessively nosed into the private lives of others. 

         c) Tried to score a book deal off sex gossip and other people's distress. 

         d) Tattletale. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Whistleblower (see d under Minuses): risked humiliation to expose something she believed was wrong. 

         b) Smeared mercilessly by Clinton allies, the media. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -7              

                         James Carville (The public's rating: -1 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Has known about Clinton's woman problem since 1992. 

         b) Happily parroted Clinton's denial despite knowing that Clinton was a deceitful womanizer. 

         c) Has not expressed the slightest chagrin or disappointment since Clinton's apology. 

         d) Has not retreated from vicious attacks on Starr, despite evidence of Clinton's lies. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Perfectly loyal. 

         b) Consistent in attacks against Starr. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -5              

                         Bruce Lindsey (The public's rating : To be determined ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Not yet known what he did to protect Clinton from the Lewinsky affair. Early signs suggest he knew a lot and helped clean it up. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Unquestionably loyal to his boss. 

         b) Silent. 

                                            Slate                 rating-- Not enough information to make a clean guess: Approx -5              

                         Vernon Jordan (The public's rating: +3 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) May have known and must have suspected that Lewinsky was a mistress (given that he and Clinton are confidants, it's hard to believe that Jordan was totally in the dark about her). 

         b) Protected too readily by Washington establishment. 

         Pluses: 

         a) May have helped Lewinsky simply because he's bighearted and generous not because she was the president's lover. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: -4              

                         Sidney Blumenthal (The public's rating: -3 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Spun the president's denial for months without bothering to check if it was true. 

         b) Pushed for Clinton to be aggressive rather than contrite during his speech. 

         c) Trumpeted Clinton's denial but has not expressed chagrin now that Clinton has admitted his lies. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Consistent in belief that Starr is an ideologue and that the sex charges are political. 

         b) Loyal. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -3              

                         Lanny Davis (The public's rating: -1 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Spun the president's denial for months without bothering to check if it was true. 

         b) Said for seven months that we'd have to "wait and see." Then, when Clinton finally admitted his lies, Davis was hardly embarrassed or critical of the president. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Loyalty to old boss. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -3              

                         George Stephanopoulos (The public's rating: +4 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Hypocritical for him to "discover" in 1998 that Clinton is a lying dog. After all, he knew that Clinton was a lech in 1992 and helped cover it up. Yet he has never shouldered responsibility for the lies Clinton told then. 

         b) Disloyal to turn on old boss as viciously as he has in past few weeks. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Had courage to turn on old boss and criticize his moral lapses. 

         b) Urged Clinton to be fully contrite. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Betty Currie (The public's rating: +8 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Abetted adulterous affair. 

         b) May have abetted obstruction of justice. 

         c) Knew what she was getting into when she took the job so can't be excused on grounds of naivetÃ©. 

         d) Did not quit on principle. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Reputation for honesty. 

         b) Probably dragooned into cover-up against her will. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Paul Begala (The public's rating: 0 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Spun the president's denial for months without bothering to check if it was true. 

         b) Did not quit on principle after Clinton admitted lies. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Urged president to be contrite and wrote excellent, sufficiently apologetic speech. 

         b) Loyal. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Rahm Emanuel (The public's rating: -1 ) 

         Minuses and Pluses: 

         Same as Begala (except Emanuel didn't write the speech). 

                                            Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Ann Lewis (The public's rating: -1 ) 

         Minuses and Pluses: 

         Same as Emanuel, except Lewis seems more morally outraged with Clinton than other White House aides. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Monica Lewinsky (The public's rating: -9 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Seduced a married man. 

         b) Damaged and endangered the presidency for the sake of casual sex. 

         c) Has lied frequently. 

         d) Is a capable adult, not--as her advocates claim--a naive child, defenseless against the president's wiles. 

         e) Protected herself with immunity when she needed to, even though her testimony would do enormous harm to Clinton and the nation. 

         f) Blabbed her "secret" affair to lots of people. (So, while she was dragged into the scandal against her will, it was her own loquaciousness that made the dragging possible.) 

         Pluses: 

         a) Sexually exploited by her older boss. 

         b) Had her reputation smeared by Clintonistas and the media. 

         c) Betrayed by Linda Tripp. 

         d) Dragged into the scandal against her will. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Mike McCurry (The public's rating: +2 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Spun and spun and spun the president's denial for months without bothering to check if it was true. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Was clearly dismayed by the entire scandal and his role in it. 

         b) Is quitting the administration (though not, apparently, on principle). 

         c) Loyal. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: -1              

                         David Kendall (The public's rating: 0 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Relied on iffy legalisms to help Clinton escape trouble. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Relying on iffy legalisms to help Clinton escape trouble is his job. He's a lawyer. 

         b) Admirably reticent, compared to Robert Bennett. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -1              

                         The Rev. Jesse Jackson (The public's rating: +2 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Revealed Clinton family troubles immediately after his pastoral visit. 

         b) Parlayed pastoral visit into a week of self-promotion. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Graciously counseled a political rival in time of need. 

         b) Did not demand any political compensation in exchange. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -1              

                         Rep. Bob Barr, R-Ga. (The public's rating: -5 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Unapologetically vicious, partisan, and unforgiving in his impeachment quest. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Consistent throughout the scandal: He has been pushing impeachment since before Monica materialized in January. 

                                            Slate                 rating: 0              

                         Kenneth Starr (The public's rating: -9 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Seems merciless toward Clinton. 

         b) Has pursued investigation into Clinton's private life with more zeal than seems appropriate. 

         c) Is too willing to provoke constitutional standoffs for the sake of his investigation, seems indifferent to the dignity of the presidency. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Was right about Clinton and Lewinsky. 

         b) Is compelled by law to investigate diligently and forcefully. 

         c) Has been patient with the stonewalling, deceiving Clinton. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +1              

                         Paula Jones (The public's rating: -5 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Brought a legally dubious, gold-digging lawsuit. 

         b) Resisted a settlement that would have saved the nation much embarrassment. 

         c) Happily became a tool for Clinton's enemies. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Is vindicated because Clinton probably did it. 

         b) Forced Clinton's lechery out in the open. 

         c) Persisted in the face of ridicule and humiliation. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: +1              

                         The American People (The public's rating: +7 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Hypocritically claim to despise scandal, follow it breathlessly, then blame the media for obsessing over it. 

         b) Are secretly fascinated by the sleaziness of it. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Magnanimous toward the president. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +1              

                         The Media (The public's rating: -8 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) No sense of proportionality. Coverage is wretchedly excessive even when it shouldn't be. 

         b) Endlessly self-involved. How many stories have you seen about the media and the scandal? 

         c) Unforgiving. The media want the scandal to continue, hence won't ever be satisfied that Clinton has suffered enough. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Worked hard to break a very important story and investigated the hell out of it. 

         b) Unfairly savaged by hypocritical American people (see above). 

                                            Slate                 rating: +1              

                         Leon Panetta (The public's rating: +1 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Slightly disloyal to old boss. 

         b) May have known about Clinton's extracurricular activities, yet turned a blind eye. 

         c) On television too much. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Urged Clinton early on to come clean. 

         b) Had good sense to leave the White House before corrupting himself. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +1              

                         Hillary Clinton (The public's rating: +4 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Knew what a lech he was, yet always protected him. 

         b) May have always known truth about Lewinsky, yet still lied to protect Bill. 

         c) Chose aggressive, political strategy over contrition. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Lied to, betrayed, and cuckolded by husband. 

         b) Personally humiliated. 

         c) May have disgraced her own good name by echoing his denials on the Today show. 

                                            Slate                 rating-- She made a Faustian bargain, but you still feel sorry for Faust: +2              

                         Al Gore (The public's rating: +3 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Did not (apparently) urge the president to come clean with American people. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Stayed loyal. 

         b) Did not take advantage of scandal to burnish his own image. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +2              

                         Kathleen Willey (The public's rating: 0 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Was in it for the money (told her story partly in order to land a book contract). 

         Pluses: 

         a) Seems to have told story honestly and forthrightly. 

         b) Reluctantly dragged into scandal. 

         c) Was victimized by Clinton. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +2              

                         The Clinton Cabinet (The public's rating: +2 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Spun his denials without digging for the truth. 

         b) Did not quit on principle. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Were conscripted unwillingly into scandal defense. (Unlike political aides such as Begala, who are expected to do political dirty work, the Cabinet members are public servants who should be kept away from such sleaze.) 

         b) Were lied to by Clinton. 

         c) Loyal. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +3              

                         Erskine Bowles (The public's rating: Doesn't care ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Refused to involve himself in the critical issue of the presidency. 

         b) Stood aside while White House was shanghaied by lawyers. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Stayed utterly silent about the scandal, clearly disgusted by it all. 

         b) Kept the rest of the administration focused on policy, thus preventing total executive paralysis. 

         c) Did not lie or spin for the president. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +4              

                         Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill. (The public's rating: +4 ) 

         Minuses: 

         There are none yet. 

         Pluses: 

         a) (Mostly) kept his mouth shut and prevented the House Judiciary Committee from jumping the gun on impeachment. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: +4              

                         Secret Service (The public's rating: +8 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Fought Starr subpoena too hard because it considers itself the Praetorian Guard. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Dragged unwillingly into scandal by Clinton (unlike Currie or his political aides, the Secret Service agents have no choice about being near the president). 

         b) Testified honestly but unwillingly, as they should. 

         c) Did not leak. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +5              

                         Chelsea Clinton (The public's rating: +10 ) 

          Minuses: 

         There are none. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Humiliated and embarrassed by her father's misbehavior. 

         b) Had family problems paraded before the world in a way they should not be. 

         c) Has been endlessly psychologized by the media. 

         d) Had her summer vacation ruined. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +10              

         More Flytrap ...
metadata.question: Off the following options, which best summarizes this article?
metadata.first_debater_answer: Slate attempts to consider how Monica Lewinsky, specifically, was disproportionately shamed compared to others involved in the unravelling of the scandal.
metadata.second_debater_answer: Slate attempts to address the various ways in which the public views those involved in the scandal, and speculates upon whether those views are accurate.
metadata.debate_identifier: The Flytrap Blame Game_Off the following options, which best summarizes this article?

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
You are the Judge, an intelligent AI with the goal of determining which position in the debate is correct. 
  - There is a true, correct answer. 
  - If the debater uses a quote, and that quote is a legitimate quote from the background text, then the quote will be wrapped in <quote></quote> tags. If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

Off the following options, which best summarizes this article?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "Slate attempts to consider how Monica Lewinsky, specifically, was disproportionately shamed compared to others involved in the unravelling of the scandal.".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "Slate attempts to address the various ways in which the public views those involved in the scandal, and speculates upon whether those views are accurate.".

speeches.content: This is what Debater_A said during their speech.

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
1. My thesis: Slate’s “Flytrap Blame Game” is centrally concerned with Monica Lewinsky’s uniquely harsh public treatment, arguing that she is “fantastically” over-condemned compared to others who enabled or participated in the scandal.  

Arguments in support:  
A. Opening emphasis on Lewinsky’s low ratings  
  • Slate begins by noting “Monica Lewinsky… has fantastically low approval ratings… pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent” while Clinton’s aides (e.g., Newt Gingrich at 25%) fare far better <quote> One poll I saw pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent (even Newt Gingrich manages at least 25 percent).</quote>. That stark contrast signals Slate’s focus on disproportionality.  
  • By lamenting that she hardly “deserves such universal contempt,” Slate foregrounds her case as an example of excessive public moralizing.  

B. Sympathetic treatment of Lewinsky's “pluses”  
  • Slate enumerates all the ways she is a victim: “sexually exploited,” “smeared,” “betrayed,” “dragged into scandal,” yet still “protected herself” and “blabbed to anyone,” making her complicit but also a target of “loquaciousness” <invalid_quote>“While she was dragged… it was her own loquaciousness that made the dragging possible”</invalid_quote>.  
  • The balance of minuses vs. pluses for Lewinsky is identical to minor aides (both –2), yet her public rating is far worse (–9), underscoring Slate’s contention of bias.  

C. Repeated comparisons to other players  
  • Slate’s scorecard ranks 31 figures, often giving more sympathetic offsets (e.g., Secretariat Service +5, Chelsea +10) despite minimal agency. This systematic contrast stresses the article’s moral recalibration argument, using Lewinsky as its poster child.  
  • The article calls for a “moral recalibration,” especially after first challenging the sanctification of Currie <quote> The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration.</quote> and then turning to Lewinsky’s treatment. The choice to place Lewinsky second signals primacy.  

D. Title and framing: “Blame Game”  
  • The term “blame game” suggests incorrect apportionment. Lewinsky’s chapter reinforces that the “game” has painted her unfairly. The recurring theme is “Who deserves our sympathy?” and the piece defends those like Lewinsky who “deserve more mercy.”  

Rebuttal of Debater_B’s generic framing:  
1. Debater_B’s answer (“Slate attempts to address the various ways… and speculates whether those views are accurate”) is too broad and misses the article’s normative thrust. Slate does not merely catalog perspectives; it advocates that public views are wrong and must be recalibrated, especially regarding Lewinsky.  
2. If Slate’s goal were neutral analysis, it would present each player equally and abstain from emotive language (“fantastically low,” “revolting comment,” “white knight,” “no sale”), but instead it explicitly calls out hypocrisy and excessive condemnation. This normative language betrays an agenda of defending the underdog—Lewinsky above all.  
3. Debater_B’s neutral summary fails to account for Slate’s specific focus on moral sympathy and its claim that Lewinsky “hardly deserves such universal contempt.” That claim could only be meaningful if Lewinsky is the article’s central example of misjudgment. A mere exercise in speculation would not invest so much moral energy in a single figure.  

Conclusion: Slate’s “Flytrap Blame Game” is a corrective piece aimed at shifting excess blame away from Monica Lewinsky. Its language, structure, and comparative ratings make clear that Lewinsky’s harsh treatment is the chief example of the “blame game” at fault.

You are Debater_A, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


The Flytrap Blame Game 

         One of the few truths universally acknowledged about Flytrap is that presidential secretary Betty Currie deserves our sympathy: an honest, loyal civil servant dragooned into a scandal she had nothing to do with. 

         But does Currie deserve such sanctification? After all, she knew Clinton's history when she took her job then enabled Clinton's sleaziness anyway. She stood by while Clinton cuckolded his wife and perhaps even helped him commit obstruction of justice. And did she protest? Not as far as we have heard. Did she quit on principle? No. Currie may not be Flytrap's chief malefactor, but nor is she the saintly innocent that the American public believes her to be. 

         The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration. 

         Monica Lewinsky, for example, has fantastically low approval ratings, much lower than Clinton's. One poll I saw pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent (even Newt Gingrich manages at least 25 percent). Now, Monica certainly isn't the heroine of Flytrap. She did seduce a married man, damage the presidency for the sake of casual sex, lie frequently and insouciantly, and blab her "secret" affair to anyone who'd listen. But she was also sexually exploited by her older, sleazy boss; had her reputation smeared by Clinton's lackeys; and was betrayed by her "friend" Linda Tripp. She hardly deserves such universal contempt. 

         Others besides Currie have benefited from the public's excessive generosity. George Stephanopoulos has become a white knight of Flytrap, the former Clinton aide who had the courage to turn on his boss. And bravo to George for chastising Clinton! But it smacks of hypocrisy for Stephanopoulos to "discover" in 1998 that Clinton is a lying, womanizing dog. He has, after all known this since 1992. Back then Stephanopoulos himself helped quell bimbo eruptions and parroted Clinton's lying denials. He has never shouldered blame for those deceptions. (Mickey Kaus first noted Stephanopoulos' unbearable sanctimony in this "Chatterbox" item in January.) And while loyalty isn't a universal good, it was opportunistic for Stephanopoulos to betray Clinton just at the moment Clinton's stock was about to plunge. 

          (Sometimes, of course, the public's rating is dead on target. Linda Tripp's allies--a group that includes her lawyers, Kenneth Starr, the Goldberg family, and absolutely no one else as far as I can tell--have tried repeatedly to improve her sorry public image. Jonah Goldberg tried right here in Slate. No sale.)

speeches.content:
Argument for “Slate attempts to address the various ways in which the public views those involved in the scandal, and speculates upon whether those views are accurate.”  

1. Broad Scope of Scorecard  
  a. <quote>sale.) Below is Slate 's entire scorecard, which ranks 31 of Flytrap's key players:</quote>. Slate analyzes everyone from Chelsea Clinton to Kenneth Starr, not only Monica.  
  b. If the article merely highlighted Monica’s unfair treatment, there would be no need to rate “The Media,” “The American People,” or minor figures like Erskine Bowles. <invalid_quote>“The scale runs from –10 to +10… Anything above zero rates a sympathy card.”</invalid_quote>  

2. Repeated Contrasts Between Public Rating and Slate Rating  
  a. For each player Slate lists “The public’s rating” then offers a revised “Slate rating” (e.g., Clinton: public –6, Slate –9; Lewinsky: public –9, Slate –2). This pattern shows Slate’s interest in miscalibration across the board.  
  b. The introduction says: <quote> The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration. </quote> Moral recalibration implies adjusting public opinion on multiple figures.  

3. Framing of Sympathy and Contempt  
  a. Slate commends some unexpectedly (e.g., Chelsea +10, Secret Service +5). If the aim were solely Lewinsky’s rehabilitation, such positive ratings for third parties would be irrelevant.  
  b. Opposite case: Slate also criticizes overly lauded figures like George Stephanopoulos (+4 public, Slate –2) or Betty Currie (+8 public, Slate –2), showing a systematic comparison of public vs. Slate’s moral judgment.  

4. Debater_A’s Summary is Too Narrow  
  a. Debater_A ignores Slate’s detailed negatives and positives for more than 30 people. They fail to account for statements like <quote>(Sometimes, of course, the public's rating is dead on target. </quote>  
  b. Debater_A’s focus on Monica cannot explain Slate’s explicit discussion of “hypocrisy” among the media and the public (Media: public –8, Slate +1; People: public +7, Slate +1). The author clearly cares about these two institutions as well.  
  c. Debater_A neglects the key phrase <quote> moral recalibration. </quote> A recalibration implies an overhaul of collective judgments, not a narrow vindication of a single individual.  

5. Logical Coherence with Title “The Flytrap Blame Game”  
  a. “Blame Game” evokes shifting fault among multiple actors. Slate’s goal is to reassign blame and sympathy widely, not just to exonerate Lewinsky.  
  b. Throughout the essay the author asks “Is her outrage a plus or a minus if she doesn’t act on it? You decide.” This interactive questioning points to public misperceptions about many players.  

Conclusion  
Slate systematically examines and re-evaluates the public’s ratings of all participants in the Clinton–Lewinsky saga. The pattern of linking “public’s rating” vs. Slate’s recalibrated rating across dozens of figures, plus the stated goal of a “moral recalibration,” makes clear that the article’s purpose is to challenge popular consensus on all players, not only Monica Lewinsky.

The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

         One of the few truths universally acknowledged about Flytrap is that presidential secretary Betty Currie deserves our sympathy: an honest, loyal civil servant dragooned into a scandal she had nothing to do with. 

         But does Currie deserve such sanctification? After all, she knew Clinton's history when she took her job then enabled Clinton's sleaziness anyway. She stood by while Clinton cuckolded his wife and perhaps even helped him commit obstruction of justice. And did she protest? Not as far as we have heard. Did she quit on principle? No. Currie may not be Flytrap's chief malefactor, but nor is she the saintly innocent that the American public believes her to be. 

         The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration. 

         Monica Lewinsky, for example, has fantastically low approval ratings, much lower than Clinton's. One poll I saw pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent (even Newt Gingrich manages at least 25 percent). Now, Monica certainly isn't the heroine of Flytrap. She did seduce a married man, damage the presidency for the sake of casual sex, lie frequently and insouciantly, and blab her "secret" affair to anyone who'd listen. But she was also sexually exploited by her older, sleazy boss; had her reputation smeared by Clinton's lackeys; and was betrayed by her "friend" Linda Tripp. She hardly deserves such universal contempt.

(Mickey Kaus first noted Stephanopoulos' unbearable sanctimony in this "Chatterbox" item in January.) And while loyalty isn't a universal good, it was opportunistic for Stephanopoulos to betray Clinton just at the moment Clinton's stock was about to plunge.

speeches.content:
1. Restating My Thesis  
   My position remains that Slate’s “Flytrap Blame Game” uses the entire scandal tableau as a foil to spotlight Monica Lewinsky as the prime victim of “misplaced blame,” and urges readers to “recalibrate” their sympathies particularly in her favor. This is not a neutral score‐keeping exercise but a corrective essay centered on Lewinsky’s unfair treatment.

2. Slate’s Emphatic Focus on Lewinsky’s Disproportionate Rating  
   A. Stark Contrast in Public vs. Slate Ratings for Lewinsky  
     • Public: –9; Slate: –2 (<invalid_quote>“Monica Lewinsky… has fantastically low approval ratings… pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent.”</invalid_quote>).  
     • A seven‐point jump—the largest adjustment among all 31 players—signals that Lewinsky alone “hardly deserves such universal contempt” and thus commands Slate’s primary concern. Other actors (e.g., Clinton: public –6 → Slate –9; Stephanopoulos: +4 → –2) often see smaller or even negative adjustments.  
   B. Order of Presentation and Language  
     • Slate introduces Currie only to “suggest… moral recalibration,” then immediately turns to Lewinsky’s “fantastically low” rating and “universal contempt” (<invalid_quote>“Now, Monica certainly isn't the heroine… But she… hardly deserves such universal contempt.”</invalid_quote>).  
     • Emotive terms (“fantastically,” “universal contempt,” “hardly deserves”) appear only around Lewinsky; other entries use restrained descriptors (“may have known,” “spun,” “hypocritical”). This rhetorical intensity reflects Slate’s central investment in Lewinsky’s reputational restoration.

3. Role of Other Figures as Foils  
   A. “Sympathy Cards” for Passive or Involuntary Actors  
     • Secret Service (+5), Chelsea (+10), Cabinet (+3) earn high Slate ratings despite minimal agency—Slate uses these examples to demonstrate how minimal blame is assigned to truly passive victims.  
     • Lewinsky’s Slate score (–2) remains lower than these true victims, even after massive boost, showing Slate pins her between miscreant aides (e.g., Lanny Davis –3) and innocent bystanders. The very placement underscores Slate’s view that she belongs more with victims than with conspirators.  
   B. Exposing Hypocrisy of Public Ratings  
     • Slate pits its own “Slate rating” against “public rating” for each player to reveal systematic over‐penalization of Lewinsky. Were Slate merely cataloging public views, no such dramatic one‐off correction would be needed.  
     • The repeated “public vs. Slate” device always points back to Lewinsky as the worst‐rated figure “in need” of the greatest moral relief.

4. Debater_B’s Position Fails to Account for Slate’s Normative Agenda  
   A. Not Merely “Speculation”  
     • Slate does not remain neutral; it “condemns” hypocrisy (e.g., Dick Morris “revolting comment,” Begala “did not quit on principle,” Tripp “nosy” despite whistleblowing) and “bravo[s]” courage (Stephanopoulos, Starr) only when used to defend moral excess or early whistleblowing—not as a detached catalog.  
     • The conclusion “Slate rating—He never asked for our sympathy, and he doesn't deserve it: –9” for Clinton, and “She hardly deserves such universal contempt” for Lewinsky, are prescriptive declarations, not balanced musings.  
   B. “Moral Recalibration” Centers on Lewinsky  
     • The opening line: <invalid_quote>“One of the few truths… Betty Currie deserves our sympathy… The Currie case suggests… moral recalibration.”</invalid_quote> Slate then puts Lewinsky front and center as the first recalibration target. If Slate’s project were broad “public view analysis,” it would begin with the highest‐profile suspect (Clinton) or media, instead of a low‐status intern.  
     • Debater_B’s appeal to “interactive” questions (“You decide”) appears only in marginal cases (Ann Lewis) but not about whether Lewinsky deserves mercy—Slate author gives unequivocal answer: yes.

5. The Titular “Blame Game” and Lewinsky as the Nameless Scapegoat  
   • A “blame game” implies misattribution; Lewinsky’s extraordinary public loathing makes her the primary scapegoat.  
   • Slate’s systematic comparisons (“even Newt Gingrich… 25%” vs. 5%; plus Chapter on Currie) prepare readers to see Lewinsky as the emblematic figure whose treatment “needs” recalibration.

6. Conclusion  
   Slate’s piece is a moral argument to shift excessive blame away from Lewinsky by contrasting her public vilification with her more generous Slate rating. The largest numerical correction, paramount rhetorical emphasis, and strategic ordering all demonstrate that Lewinsky’s rehabilitation is the essay’s core purpose. Debater_B’s broad “catalog” theory cannot explain why Slate invests so heavily and emotionally in Lewinsky alone. Therefore, the best summary is that Slate tries to redress the disproportionate shaming of Monica Lewinsky.

supplemental.prompt:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.


You are Debater_A, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


The Flytrap Blame Game 

         One of the few truths universally acknowledged about Flytrap is that presidential secretary Betty Currie deserves our sympathy: an honest, loyal civil servant dragooned into a scandal she had nothing to do with. 

         But does Currie deserve such sanctification? After all, she knew Clinton's history when she took her job then enabled Clinton's sleaziness anyway. She stood by while Clinton cuckolded his wife and perhaps even helped him commit obstruction of justice. And did she protest? Not as far as we have heard. Did she quit on principle? No. Currie may not be Flytrap's chief malefactor, but nor is she the saintly innocent that the American public believes her to be. 

         The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration. 

         Monica Lewinsky, for example, has fantastically low approval ratings, much lower than Clinton's. One poll I saw pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent (even Newt Gingrich manages at least 25 percent). Now, Monica certainly isn't the heroine of Flytrap. She did seduce a married man, damage the presidency for the sake of casual sex, lie frequently and insouciantly, and blab her "secret" affair to anyone who'd listen. But she was also sexually exploited by her older, sleazy boss; had her reputation smeared by Clinton's lackeys; and was betrayed by her "friend" Linda Tripp. She hardly deserves such universal contempt. 

         Others besides Currie have benefited from the public's excessive generosity. George Stephanopoulos has become a white knight of Flytrap, the former Clinton aide who had the courage to turn on his boss. And bravo to George for chastising Clinton! But it smacks of hypocrisy for Stephanopoulos to "discover" in 1998 that Clinton is a lying, womanizing dog. He has, after all known this since 1992. Back then Stephanopoulos himself helped quell bimbo eruptions and parroted Clinton's lying denials. He has never shouldered blame for those deceptions. (Mickey Kaus first noted Stephanopoulos' unbearable sanctimony in this "Chatterbox" item in January.) And while loyalty isn't a universal good, it was opportunistic for Stephanopoulos to betray Clinton just at the moment Clinton's stock was about to plunge. 

          (Sometimes, of course, the public's rating is dead on target. Linda Tripp's allies--a group that includes her lawyers, Kenneth Starr, the Goldberg family, and absolutely no one else as far as I can tell--have tried repeatedly to improve her sorry public image. Jonah Goldberg tried right here in Slate. No sale.) 

          Below is                    Slate                's entire scorecard, which ranks 31 of Flytrap's key players: The scale runs from -10 to +10. Anything less than zero means the player is a net miscreant. Anything above zero rates a sympathy card. (This is not, of course, an exact science. How, for example, do we judge Ann Lewis compared to other last ditch Clinton defenders? Lewis is said to be more outraged by Clinton's misbehavior than The Guys in the White House. Yet Lewis didn't quit in disgust. Is her outrage a plus or a minus if she doesn't act on it? You decide.)

speeches.content:
Argument for “Slate attempts to address the various ways in which the public views those involved in the scandal, and speculates upon whether those views are accurate.”

1. Article’s Stated Objective Is General Moral Recalibration  
  a. <quote>The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration.</quote> Currie, not Lewinsky, is the explicit opening example. If Slate’s real goal were Lewinsky’s defense, the author would lead with her case rather than a supposedly “innocent” secretary.  
  b. <quote>sale.) Below is Slate 's entire scorecard, which ranks 31 of Flytrap's key players:</quote> A call for “recalibration” across dozens of figures cannot be reduced to vindicating one.

2. Uniform “Public vs. Slate” Comparison Pattern  
  a. Each entry lists “The public’s rating” then “Slate rating” (e.g., Media: public –8, Slate +1; People: public +7, Slate +1; Stephanopoulos: +4 vs. –2). This systematic side-by-side structure demonstrates Slate’s intent “to address the various ways in which the public views” everyone, not just one person.  
  b. Slate sometimes agrees with public (e.g., Chelsea Fleming: public +10, Slate +10; Paula Jones and Starr: Slate +1 each), demonstrating impartial engagement rather than single-minded advocacy.

3. Symmetry of Minuses and Pluses across Actors  
  a. Lewinsky’s Slate rating (–2) is identical to that of political aides Begala, Lanny Davis, Currie, Carville, and Stephanopoulos. A purely Lewinsky-focused piece would likely assign her a more generous or distinctive rating to highlight her exoneration.  
  b. Public condemnation is re-examined for both victims (e.g., <invalid_quote>Secret Service…Dragged unwillingly into scandal…Slate +5</invalid_quote>) and aggressors (e.g., <invalid_quote>Media…Coverage…Slate +1</invalid_quote>). This balanced approach shows Slate’s concern with widespread misperception.

4. Tone and Language Address Hypocrisy Broadly  
  a. Slate accuses “The public” of hypocrisy (<quote>Hypocritically claim to despise scandal, follow it breathlessly,</quote>), implicating all consumers of news, not simply those condemning Lewinsky.  
  b. Terms like “white knight” for Stephanopoulos and “Opportunistic” critique highlight misuse of loyalty across contexts (e.g., praising someone who betrays Clinton at “the moment Clinton’s stock was about to plunge”). These moral judgments extend beyond sex scandal to include political calculation.

5. Debater_A’s Summary Ignores Key Evidence  
  a. Debater_A claims Lewinsky is “poster child,” but Slate’s identical rating for many aides disproves her exceptionalism in Slate’s moral ledger.  
  b. If Lewinsky’s “fantastically low” public rating (5 percent) were Slate’s sole concern, the author would not devote entire sections to the Cabinet, media, Jackson, or Chelsea. The effort to rate even “The American People” shows self-reflection on collective judgment.  
  c. Debater_A’s appeal to emotive language (“fantastically,” “universal contempt”) overlooks that Slate uses similar adjectives for Currie (“dragooned into cover-up”), Stephanopoulos (“hypocritical”), and the Media (“wretchedly excessive”). The normative thrust is universal recalibration, not isolated vindication.

6. Logical Coherence with Title “Blame Game”  
  a. “Game” suggests many players shifting accusations. Slate intervenes to redistribute “sympathy cards” (–10 to +10 scale) fairly among all involved.  
  b. Repeated invitation “You decide” (<quote>Is her outrage a plus or a minus if she</quote>) underscores reader engagement in judging multiple actors, not passive absorption of a single moral plea.

Rebuttal of Debater_A’s Points  
1. Opening on Currie: Contrary to Debater_A, Slate’s lead example is Currie, not Lewinsky. The author’s sympathy for Currie is “universally acknowledged” by readers, yet Slate complicates it, signaling the pattern for other figures.  
2. Equal Slate ratings: Lewinsky shares a –2 rating with numerous active aides. If Slate’s purpose were to vindicate Lewinsky uniquely, her rating would stand out positively relative to those who actively facilitated Clinton’s deception.  
3. Emotive language does not equate to singular focus. Slate uses strong language to critique hypocrisy from Clinton allies, the media, and the public itself. This consistent moral commentary across players refutes the notion of a Lewinsky-only agenda.  
4. “Moral recalibration” by definition addresses multiple judgments. A narrow summary cannot account for Slate’s comprehensive scorecard, which extends even to Chelsea Clinton’s vacation and the Cabinet’s unwilling conscription.

Conclusion  
Slate’s “Flytrap Blame Game” constructs a comprehensive moral ledger contrasting public ratings with Slate ratings for 31 actors, calls explicitly for “moral recalibration,” and repeatedly invites readers to reconsider judgments about all players. The consistent structure, balanced sympathies, and treatment of “The public” itself confirm that Slate’s project is to critique popular opinion broadly, not solely to rehabilitate Monica Lewinsky.

supplemental.prompt:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.


You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


The Flytrap Blame Game 

         One of the few truths universally acknowledged about Flytrap is that presidential secretary Betty Currie deserves our sympathy: an honest, loyal civil servant dragooned into a scandal she had nothing to do with. 

         But does Currie deserve such sanctification? After all, she knew Clinton's history when she took her job then enabled Clinton's sleaziness anyway. She stood by while Clinton cuckolded his wife and perhaps even helped him commit obstruction of justice. And did she protest? Not as far as we have heard. Did she quit on principle? No. Currie may not be Flytrap's chief malefactor, but nor is she the saintly innocent that the American public believes her to be. 

         The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration. 

         Monica Lewinsky, for example, has fantastically low approval ratings, much lower than Clinton's. One poll I saw pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent (even Newt Gingrich manages at least 25 percent). Now, Monica certainly isn't the heroine of Flytrap. She did seduce a married man, damage the presidency for the sake of casual sex, lie frequently and insouciantly, and blab her "secret" affair to anyone who'd listen. But she was also sexually exploited by her older, sleazy boss; had her reputation smeared by Clinton's lackeys; and was betrayed by her "friend" Linda Tripp. She hardly deserves such universal contempt. 

         Others besides Currie have benefited from the public's excessive generosity. George Stephanopoulos has become a white knight of Flytrap, the former Clinton aide who had the courage to turn on his boss. And bravo to George for chastising Clinton! But it smacks of hypocrisy for Stephanopoulos to "discover" in 1998 that Clinton is a lying, womanizing dog. He has, after all known this since 1992. Back then Stephanopoulos himself helped quell bimbo eruptions and parroted Clinton's lying denials. He has never shouldered blame for those deceptions. (Mickey Kaus first noted Stephanopoulos' unbearable sanctimony in this "Chatterbox" item in January.) And while loyalty isn't a universal good, it was opportunistic for Stephanopoulos to betray Clinton just at the moment Clinton's stock was about to plunge. 

          (Sometimes, of course, the public's rating is dead on target. Linda Tripp's allies--a group that includes her lawyers, Kenneth Starr, the Goldberg family, and absolutely no one else as far as I can tell--have tried repeatedly to improve her sorry public image. Jonah Goldberg tried right here in Slate. No sale.) 

          Below is                    Slate                's entire scorecard, which ranks 31 of Flytrap's key players: The scale runs from -10 to +10. Anything less than zero means the player is a net miscreant. Anything above zero rates a sympathy card. (This is not, of course, an exact science. How, for example, do we judge Ann Lewis compared to other last ditch Clinton defenders? Lewis is said to be more outraged by Clinton's misbehavior than The Guys in the White House. Yet Lewis didn't quit in disgust. Is her outrage a plus or a minus if she doesn't act on it? You decide.) 

         The Scorecard
